title: After the Romans: Manchester 410-1066
description: Manchester's last Roman coins date to ~340 AD. For the next 580 years, the site disappears from the record entirely — no archaeology, no texts, nothing — until Edward the Elder fortifies 'Mameceastre' in the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle entry for 919. The place-name survived in the Brittonic tradition as Cair Maunguid (Historia Brittonum, ~828), proving someone remembered the fort. Anglo-Saxon settlers arrived on the Irk/Irwell confluence, bringing the open-field farming system that would outlast everything. But of their lives we know almost nothing — they left no inscriptions, no documents, no maps. The closest we get to a documented Romano-British family in the North-West is St Patrick's Confessio (~mid-5th century), describing his father Calpurnius's villa estate somewhere in western Britain, with a functioning church and enough wealth to attract Irish slave raids.
